Mr . Bixby
-
3 -
September 22, 1937
that nations manage to get small arm ammunition somehow or other in spite
the most rigorous restrictions, and with this type of supplies alone the
Chinese should be able to keep up a devastating guerilla warfare for a
very long period.
After all, they have only one chance of winning, or
shall we say saving themselves, in this war and that is to bleed Japan eco-
nomically and financially white by forcing her to keep a very large army
mobile in the field for a long period.
If they do,
something is going to
crack badly in Japan, I think,
before anything cracks in China.
It is for
this reason that I cannot believe in any
return to peaceful conditions in
the future as far ahead as I can see-which means, of course, that in my
opinion there is not the slightest chance of our resuming operations or
participating in operations in China even if we were disposed to make the
necessary further investment.
I have felt all along that the possibility of our operating
not so much because of the fail-
are of the chinese to cooperate luoy out 1a beca the top-fad -
men would do that in their own interests) but because I felt sure that the
Japanese would never discriminate between military and conmercial aircraft,
with the result that our pilots could not have flown with any reasonable
in chine so long as Japanese meteor wireal not sette can tati
if that is correct then we could not safely resume operations
territory, even although a state of comparative peace might materialize and
our Chinese friends should give new and
possibly more satisfactory assur-
ances of
their willingness to cooperate.
Possibly you will disagree with a good deal of the above and
it would be interesting to have your comment, as I make no claims
to omni-
science.
lating,
In any case,
correspondence of this sort is interesting and stimu-
like a game of
chess by cable.
Sincerely yours,
